editionStmt.edition: Based on the Locations List from the Short Title Catalogue, this list regularizes abbreviated location information. Superscript numbers are presented in-line. No attempt has been made to update information to reflect subsequent shifts in location of private individuals or collections. Cross-references to ESTC IDs are taken from estc.bl.uk, where possible.

availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported License

titleStmt.title: A Short-Title Catalogue of Books Printed in England, Scotland, & Ireland and of English Books Printed Abroad 1475 - 1640

projectDesc.p: Location codes are used to designate the library or repository holding a specific copy of a rare book. Three major systems in use today are the Short Title Catalogue location codes, the MARC code list for organizations, and the English Short Title Catalogue location codes, which employ a modified MARC code.

The STC codes were originally developed in the 1920s to reference copies listed in Pollard and Redgrave's A Short-Title Catalogue of Books Printed in England, Scotland, & Ireland and of English Books Printed Abroad 1475 - 1640. STC location codes are largely city-based system, so the libraries in London are L, those in Oxford are O, and so on, followed by a number to differentiate them. This system is not wholly consistent, so some major libraries simply have their first initial as a designation, such as the Folger Shakespeare Library (F).

MARC, or "MAchine Readable Cataloging" is a set of standards developed by the Library of Congress in the 1960s to facilitate the sharing of library records. The basic pattern for MARC codes is the first letter of the state, followed by the first letter(s) of the repository. Subunits of an institution are then added, if needed: so Harvard, in Massachusetts, may be referred to generally as MH, while the Houghton is MH-H.

The English Short Title Catalogue, estc.bl.uk, the successor to the Short Title Catalogue, adopted a modified MARC code for North American holdings. The "library code" field prefaces the MARC code with a continental disambiguator: n = North America, e = Europe. There is no connection on the ESTC website between the historic STC library code and the modern ESTC library code. This list hopes to remedy this problem.

editorialDecl.p: This text is derived from a scan of the "Locations" list printed in the copy of the STC held at the Folger Shakespeare Library. Abbreviated place names have been expanded, and some information has been duplicated where doing so makes the entry clearer.
Entries were cross-checked against the ESTC (estc.bl.uk), and where available, ESTC location codes are supplied. No attempt has been made to locate works listed in private collections.
